Basic usage of XAMPP

Open source cross-platform web server solution stack package, 26th Jan, 2017

Here, I am going to discuss how to do basic configuration and usage of XAMPP. But first let's see what is XAMPP? Basically, XAMPP stands for Cross-Platform (X), Apache (A), MariaDB (M), PHP (P) and Perl (P). Previously M stood for MySQL. As wiki says "It is a simple, lightweight Apache distribution that makes it extremely easy for developers to create a local web server for testing and deployment purposes.", using XAMPP one can easily host websites. So let's take a look into it...
One can download the XAMPP from Apache friends website. It is a cross-platform package which means it works equally well on Linux, Mac and Windows. Installation can be completed by following the instructions.
Now after the installation is complete, invoke manager-osx (in MacOS, one can find it in the Applications folder in the finder). In the tab, Manage Servers one can see three options "MySQL Database", "ProFTPD" and "Apache Web Server". Start Apache Web Server. One can see the configuration file using the button "Configure". From the configuration files, One can configure the root as well as log directory. By default the root directory is configured as htdocs folder. We will see more about the configuration files in my next blog "Apache Configuration" where we will also discuss about virtual hosting. Now let's focus on our simple website hosting using XAMPP.
After starting the Apache Web Server, create an index.html/index.php file in the root directory. Use now localhost in the web browser. This is how a basic website can be hosted using XAMPP.
